number of helpful: 23 of 28 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Agree with the guy who said he got mugged!After a long struggle I finally managed to get this game working and I spent more time trying to fix it than playing the actual game. I had major issues trying to run this game. First of all it would just crash on start up so run as Admin. Then I run the game and I get a glowing white screen! So I goto graphics options to see what I can do. I decide to put graphics up to high and turn off the glowing effect. There's 2 options to switch off for glowing effect.For some reson what I did completly messed up the game and crashed everytime on start up. So I give up. A few months lather I re-install my OS and decid to try it one more time. It worked! but I still had a glowing white screen! So I carfully changed the glow settings (dynamic lighting or somthing) and everythhing seems to run ok! From what I gather the graphics settings are saved seperate to the actual Hotel Giant install root folder (It was for me!) meaning that even a re-install of the game would not reset the games graphics  settings to default. Leaving me with graphics settings that crashed the game and unable to change back. Normally these settings are saved in a text file somewhere, so If anyone else is having these problems maybe your graphics settings are causing it and the only fix is to find that file to manually edit (which strangly is not in the Hotel Giant install directory nor Steam/apps/common/HotelGiant2) or re-install OS (which is a bit overkill just to get this crap game to work)This is just terrible and to me this code is all broken. They released an update a few months back and this was not even touched upon?

number of helpful: 25 of 33 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
Product received for free
Basic InformationTitle:  Hotel Giant 2 HDDeveloper:  Enlight Software Limited & PerspectX 	Publisher:  United Independent Entertainment	Genre:  Economic SimulatorGeneral ImpressionHotel Giant 2 was released in 2010, but received in 2015 an HD update which has met a lukewarm reception. And with good reasons too. While the game looks very good for an economic sim, it crashes quite a lot (so I definitely suggest saving your progress every 30 minutes or so) even without the visual and sound glitches that were never ironed out since its initial release. If you can overlook these flaws, you’ll find a thoroughly efficient hotel simulator which lets you control everything from planning, building and managing the financial side of business as well. The gameplay mechanics are far from broken and you can find an educational purpose to this title. So don’t avoid it, thinking it’s a bad or generic game. It’s far from it.Strong Points+ Nice graphical details.+ Complex economic simulation.+ Steam Achievements.Weak Points- Relatively frequent crashes and glitches.- No Steam Trading Cards.Rating 6/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews.

Posted: January 1
												I played the original Hotel Giant ten years ago for dozens of hours. It was very fun to decorate and have 100% satisfaction in all rooms and make thousands of dollars to make more hotels. This game is pretty much the same with a few new additions, and it delivers the same experience but with full compatibility with Windows 10 and full HD. I recommend this game because I loved then and I still love it. This a budget game thought, so it's pretty basic and doesnt provide much of a challenge. Is all about making an hotel, dominate the market and make millions of dollars. I did it once with a chain of motels in Hotel Giant and I'm very excited in doing the same in Hotel Giant 2.

content:
Posted: January 28
												Folks, if your screen goes white at main menu, just go to options and take off 'glow effect'. I tried this on the recommendation of other posters here, regardless of the negative commentary and my game is fine, and totally playable. For it's time, Hotel Giant is a pretty seamless experience. I've played worse games, and I did enjoy this one. Sadly, it seems it is the only one of its type out there, so we have little choice in the matter, if you want to be a Hotel tycoon. Pro's: Great graphics, reasonably easy building system, and still challenging getting your coverage up to 'all rooms full'. This version, being HG2, includes a lot more shops...originally, there were only three, now there are a good few more, including 'Arts & Crafts', Coffee shop, and some others. More content added that I might not have seen yet, as I am still enjoying my playthrough. Cons: It does seem that the punters don't give a damn if the room is done out in a hundred mismatched materials, if only all the top priced furnishings are used ..which gives them nothing to complain about eventually, but also means you can't do the decorating completely your way, from a colour scheme pov.  Also, there is not enough micromanagement of any service available in the Hotel. I'd also expect cleaners, if nothing else, but I guess we can't have everything,Overall, it's still a good time sinker while you play it out. For a mere fiver and change, it's hardly vast in content, so you get what you pay for.  I'll still stand behind it, as a 'Good Old Game.'

number of helpful: 8 of 24 people (33%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2012
												You start the game as a small two star chain hotel manager. For you, life is cheap and your hourly rates are cheaper. Little by little you slowly devour customers and their possessions until you reach critical mass, allowing you to bribe hotel officials and pushing you up a star rating.Upon reaching a grand total of fire stars, the hotel drops the pretence of accommodation and uproots itself from its earthly bounds and begins rampaging through a downtown of your choosing. This is where the game really flys off the deep end interms of balance and replayability. Sure its cool watching a Novatel claw its way up the Chrysler building and swat angrily at bi-planes, but after the first time it gets fairly stale.The controls are dodgy and sluggish (You're a fifteen story hotel, I guess it was intended) and the concept is frankly ridiculously. I got it for a buck. Don't bother. There are better sentient building simulators out there.

												Surprisingly(I say because this is a UIG product), I've quite enjoyed this game and have been able to negate display issues. The white 'glow' was very easy to deal with by changing the settings menu 'glow' setting to 'off'(HD Update). After playing both this version(HG2) and the original(HG), I still feel as though I can put hours more into this game. The menus are very intricate and can be confusing, but as with all games, once you navigate them a few times, you learn where they are and what their hot-keys are.
